p:
During the SARS outbreak in 2002 to 2003, there were reports of viral RNA being found in fecal samples, occasionally even after 30 days after symptoms onset, determining a risk for the stools to become a source of contamination of airdrops and several environmental surfaces.
3 In children, SARS-CoV infection was associated to gastrointestinal symptoms, but there is no evidence of rectal swabs being performed for diagnosis and further surveillance.
